Award.AwardTitle: Mitochondrial fitness variation in a naturally replicated evolutionary experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animal genomes contain millions of functionally significant sites in their DNA sequences and are therefore large targets for mutation. Some mutational differences among genomes have individually large effects, but many others have effects too small to allow measurable differences in particular traits to be attributed to them. In theory, the "mutations of small effect" could collectively account for most of the heritable variation in many traits, but whether they actually do is still unknown owing to the difficulty of studying mutations whose effects cannot be seen directly. Using six closely related species of marine invertebrates (Amphipoda: Cyamus) that have lived in unusually well defined and constant environments for more than five million years, this project will develop a sensitive method for characterizing mutations with very small effects. Over thousands of generations, tiny differences in the performances of the small, simple, non-recombining mitochondrial genomes of these animals are predicted to have large, easily detected effects on the sizes and shapes of their genealogies. The abundances of mutations with various different effect sizes will be inferred from the genealogical distortions together with the histories of mutation in each species.

The combined effects of many mutations with individually small effects may influence many traits of scientific, agricultural and medical importance, including disease susceptibilities and patterns of aging, substantially. This work will complement ongoing attempts to understand the genetics of such traits, by revealing the nature and scale of the contributions from small-effect mutations in a simple and well-defined natural system. This award will also support graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Utah and contribute to a GK-12 project already underway in area high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Finding the mutations that matter.  Some mutations have large effects on the individuals that carry them.  Genetics was the study of such mutations through most of the 20th century, because they are easy to identify.  We now know that most mutations have very small effects, if any, and that collectively these cause most of the heritable variation seen among the members of a typical plant or animal population.  But which of the many mutational differences between two individuals are the ones that made them differ in other respects, and how did those mutations make that happen?  We still do not know even approximately how many mutations contribute to the variation of a typical trait, much less which particular mutations are the ones that contribute, even though we can now see all of the candidates by sequencing genomes.  The answers will be important as basic science, and they also will bear on a wide range of specific issues in developmental biology, physiology, evolution, and even medicine, where our susceptibilities to many kinds of diseases are increasingly recognized as having diffuse rather than discrete genetic influences.

Natural selection can slowly change the abundances of mutations that have imperceptibly small effects on health, performance and reproduction.  If selection on a trait is fairly consistent over many generations, then a population's stock of genetic variation may change in ways that can easily be measured.  This is true even when selection favors not changing.  In that case, most new mutations will be slightly harmful and selection will weakly oppose them. 

Intellectual merit.  The main goal of this project was to look for signals of diffuse selection in the small, non-recombining mitochondrial genomes of six species of marine crustaceans (amphipods in the family Cyamidae, hence "cyamids").  These highly specialized relatives of skeleton shrimp live on right whales.  Their ecology is extremely simple and well defined, and we know it hasn't changed appreciably for millions of years, because they and their hosts seem virtually identical on both sides of the equator, which they no longer cross at detectable rates.

We determined the DNA sequences of several thousand copies of an important mitochondrial gene, and of more than 1000 complete mitochondrial genomes.  Because they are inherited maternally without bi-parental recombination, almost every surviving mitochondrial mutation can be mapped to its time and place in the female genealogy of its species.  We developed methods for estimating the numbers and effect sizes of very slightly harmful mutations (the majority) by analyzing the shapes of the genealogies, and we identified a smaller number of beneficial mutations that have increased, in parallel, from many independent mutational origins.

We had expected to find evidence that large numbers of mutations that are traditionally assumed to be harmless ("neutral") are in fact slightly harmful, and we did.  We were not looking for beneficial or "adaptive" mutations, but they were easy to see in our large sample of mitochondrial DNA sequences.  The ages of those apparently beneficial mutations suggest that they may have adapted the cyamids to environmental changes caused by the glacial climate cycles that have intensified during the last few million years.  Almost none of the mutations (bad or good) change the structures of the proteins encoded by the genes in which they occur, implying that they affect fitness by modifying their protein's expression.  Our findings support the emerging view that gene expression is controlled in very complex and multi-layered ways that cannot avoid being continually readjusted by evolution, and that much of the variation seen within typical species is a consequence of this never-ending process. 

Broader impacts.  This project provided research training for many undergraduates, several high-school students and one graduate student, most of them women.  And most attended international scientific meetings where they presented posters on their work.

Variation is fundamental to biology but still poorly understood by most educated people including most biologists.  We developed a new laboratory course for first-semester freshmen (The Biology of Variation), in which the students do real research projects on the genetic and environmental causes of variation in quaking aspen.  They work in small teams to develop a question and a research plan, peer-review each other's proposals, analyze their data using the R statistical programming language, write a formal report, and present their project as a short scientific talk.  The goal is to help these beginning university students quickly transition from seeing themselves as unskilled consumers of scientific knowledge, to seeing themselves also as skilled producers of scientific questions and investigations.  We had hoped that this change of perspective would enable them to engage more actively and productively with their subsequent courses and with scientific issues that arise in the public sphere, and this does seem to happen.  Former students consistently report that they have become more independent and confident as scientific thinkers.
